questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding anterior uveitis is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Iris atrophy in acute anterior uveitis presents with a diffuse pattern.

options.label: B
options.text: Circumcorneal congestion is absent in granulomatous anterior uveitis.

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior synechiae formation is a common complication.

options.label: D
options.text: Busacca nodules are located at the pupillary margin.

questions.correct_answer: C. Posterior synechiae formation is a common complication.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior synechiae formation is a common complication.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior synechiae formation is a hallmark complication of anterior uveitis, leading to significant sequelae if untreated.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would most strongly support cavernous sinus thrombosis over orbital cellulitis?

options.label: C
options.text: Severe restriction of extraocular movements in the affected eye

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of systemic fever and leukocytosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Bilateral periorbital edema and chemosis
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Bilateral periorbital involvement is a hallmark of cavernous sinus thrombosis and helps distinguish it from unilateral conditions such as orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of corneal dystrophy, inheritance pattern, and primary defect is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Lattice corneal dystrophy, autosomal dominant, amyloid deposits

options.label: B
options.text: Meesmann epithelial dystrophy, autosomal recessive, hyaline deposits

options.label: C
options.text: Fuchs endothelial dystrophy, autosomal dominant, keratin sulfate deposits

options.label: D
options.text: Granular corneal dystrophy, X-linked recessive, lipid deposits

questions.correct_answer: A. Lattice corneal dystrophy, autosomal dominant, amyloid deposits
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lattice corneal dystrophy, autosomal dominant, amyloid deposits

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lattice corneal dystrophy is autosomal dominant and involves amyloid deposits in the stroma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of progressive high myopia undergoes fundus examination, revealing a tigroid pattern. What is the primary cause of this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Thinning of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

questions.correct_answer: A. Thinning of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thinning of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tigroid fundus in pathological myopia is due to thinning of the retinal pigment epithelium and choroid, exposing the underlying choroidal vessels.

questions.text: The percentage of atropine present in atropine drops as cycloplegic is:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 1%

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with blurry vision and asthenopia. On examination, her corneal topography shows a more curved horizontal meridian compared to the vertical meridian. Which type of regular astigmatism is this?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Against-the-rule astigmatism occurs when the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian, causing refractive errors specific to this axis.

questions.text: During testing with the device shown, the patient is asked to compare two orientations of the lens. What is being assessed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cylindrical axis and power

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Jackson’s cross-cylinder test is used to refine the axis and power of astigmatism during subjective refraction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is undergoing retinoscopy for unexplained visual blur. The red reflex moves against the retinoscope’s motion in the vertical meridian, but there is no reflex motion observed in the horizontal meridian. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Compound myopic astigmatism is characterized by myopia in both meridians, with differing degrees of refractive error that lead to varied reflex motion during retinoscopy.

questions.text: Economic blindness is defined when visual acuity falls below
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 6/60

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has a near point at 50 cm due to presbyopia. What changes in the lens occur during accommodation to bring objects closer into focus?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior lens curvature decreases, lens thickness increases, anterior chamber depth increases

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior lens curvature increases, lens thickness increases, anterior chamber depth decreases

options.label: C
options.text: Equatorial lens thickness increases, anterior lens curvature decreases, anterior chamber depth decreases

options.label: D
options.text: Lens curvature and thickness remain unchanged, only zonules relax

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior lens curvature increases, lens thickness increases, anterior chamber depth decreases
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior lens curvature increases, lens thickness increases, anterior chamber depth decreases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Accommodation involves increased anterior lens curvature, increased lens thickness, and a decrease in anterior chamber depth.

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypermetropic patient with a refractive error of +2 D is evaluated for accommodation. Her near point is at 10 cm. What is the amplitude of accommodation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 12 D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hypermetropia, the far point lies behind the retina, and the refractive power for far and near points is summed to calculate the amplitude of accommodation.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would be an absolute contraindication to LASIK surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Corneal thickness of 470 microns

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LASIK is contraindicated in patients with corneal thickness <470 microns due to the risk of postoperative ectasia.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with severe, gradual, progressive loss of vision in both eyes. He has been wearing spectacles since the age of 5 and has a refractive error of -8D. A B-scan image (as shown) was obtained during evaluation. What is the most likely finding on the B-scan?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior staphyloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior staphyloma is a hallmark of pathological myopia, characterized by outpouching of the posterior sclera seen on B-scan imaging and associated with progressive visual decline.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a use of the stenopaic slit?

options.label: A
options.text: Differentiation of halos in cataract versus angle-closure glaucoma

options.label: B
options.text: Determination of the axis of cylindrical refractive error

options.label: D
options.text: Determination of the meridian for optical iridectomy

questions.correct_answer: C. Assistance in corneal tattooing procedures
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Assistance in corneal tattooing procedures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The stenopaic slit is used in diagnostic procedures like Fincham’s test, determining the axis of astigmatism, and aligning the meridian for optical iridectomy but has no role in corneal tattooing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of eye irritation and blurred vision in his right eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist applies a specific dye to the patient's eye and visualizes it under a particular filter. The image is shown below. What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

options.label: B
options.text: Lissamine dye - visualised under green filter

options.label: C
options.text: Lissamine dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

options.label: D
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.correct_answer: A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluorescein dye is used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and is visualized under a cobalt blue filter, which emits a bright green fluorescence.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Duane’s retraction syndrome. Which of the following laws governing binocular single vision is most relevant in this condition?
questions.correct_answer: B. Sherrington’s law of reciprocal inhibition
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sherrington’s law of reciprocal inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sherrington’s law of reciprocal inhibition governs the interaction between agonist and antagonist muscles and is disrupted in conditions like Duane’s retraction syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is diagnosed with Squint. Hirschberg’s corneal reflex test shows the corneal reflex displaced nasally. What does this finding indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exodeviation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hirschberg’s test evaluates ocular alignment by noting the position of the corneal reflex, with nasal displacement indicating exodeviation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient complains of diplopia and an abnormal head posture with a chin-down position. Examination reveals positive forced duction testing for the inferior rectus muscle in both eyes. Which systemic condition is most likely contributing to these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Graves’ orbitopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Positive FDT with chin-down posture strongly suggests inferior rectus restriction, as seen in Graves’ orbitopathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with diabetes presents with vertical diplopia that worsens when descending stairs. Examination reveals a head tilt to the left. Which eye movement is most likely impaired?

options.label: A
options.text: Depression and abduction of the right eye

options.label: B
options.text: Depression and adduction of the left eye

options.label: C
options.text: Elevation and abduction of the right eye

options.label: D
options.text: Elevation and adduction of the left eye

questions.correct_answer: B. Depression and adduction of the left eye
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Depression and adduction of the left eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superior oblique palsy impairs depression and adduction, leading to compensatory contralateral head tilt.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with impaired horizontal gaze but intact vertical gaze. Imaging shows a lesion in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). Which of the following is most likely observed?

options.label: A
options.text: Complete paralysis of horizontal gaze to both sides

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired horizontal gaze to the ipsilateral side of the lesion

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired horizontal gaze to the contralateral side of the lesion

options.label: D
options.text: Intact horizontal and vertical gaze due to redundancy in cortical control

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired horizontal gaze to the ipsilateral side of the lesion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Impaired horizontal gaze to the ipsilateral side of the lesion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The PPRF generates horizontal saccades to the ipsilateral side, and lesions cause ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with complaints of intermittent diplopia. The test shown in the image is conducted. Which of the following conditions is most accurately diagnosed using this test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Heterophoria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maddox rod test is primarily used to detect and measure heterophorias by dissociating the eyes and assessing latent deviations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of glaucoma presents to the clinic for follow-up. The ophthalmologist decides to adjust the patient's medication to better control intraocular pressure. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Latanoprost

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a 3rd ventricular glioma. Which visual field defect is most likely seen, and what is the anatomical reason?

options.label: A
options.text: Bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of nasal fibers in the optic chiasm

options.label: B
options.text: Homonymous hemianopia due to compression of the optic radiations

options.label: C
options.text: Central scotoma due to compression of the optic nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Superior altitudinal defect due to ischemia of the retina

questions.correct_answer: A. Bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of nasal fibers in the optic chiasm
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of nasal fibers in the optic chiasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Third ventricular gliomas cause bitemporal hemianopia by compressing the superior nasal fibers of the optic chiasm.

questions.text: A newborn presents with swollen eyelids and purulent discharge 3 days after birth. The baby was delivered vaginally, and the mother had no prenatal care. The image shows the affected eyes of the newborn. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ophthalmia neonatorum
  • ➤ Ophthalmia neonatorum

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis presents with sudden monocular vision loss. Which of the following findings would best differentiate retrobulbar neuritis from other types of optic neuritis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Normal fundus examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retrobulbar neuritis is characterized by a normal fundus due to inflammation occurring behind the eyeball.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of untreated chronic hypertension presents with visual disturbances and severe headache. Fundoscopy finding is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely associated visual field defect?
questions.correct_answer: C. Enlargement of the blind spot
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enlargement of the blind spot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visual field defects in papilledema commonly include blind spot enlargement due to optic disc swelling.

questions.text: Identify and match the following tonometer’s with their respective image in column B Column A 1. Schiøtz tonometer 2. Goldmann tonometer 3. Non-contact air-puff tonometer 4. Pekins tonometer Column B
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Schiøtz Tonometer : Useful for assessing IOP in basic setups. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer : The gold standard for IOP measurement and provides highly accurate readings in most patients. Non-contact Air-puff Tonometer : A screening tool for quick IOP measurement without corneal contact, especially useful in non-clinical environments. Perkins Tonometer : A portable applanation tonometer used for bedridden patients or children.
  • ➤ Schiøtz Tonometer : Useful for assessing IOP in basic setups.
  • ➤ Schiøtz Tonometer
  • ➤ Goldmann Applanation Tonometer : The gold standard for IOP measurement and provides highly accurate readings in most patients.
  • ➤ Goldmann Applanation Tonometer
  • ➤ Non-contact Air-puff Tonometer : A screening tool for quick IOP measurement without corneal contact, especially useful in non-clinical environments.
  • ➤ Non-contact Air-puff Tonometer
  • ➤ Perkins Tonometer : A portable applanation tonometer used for bedridden patients or children.
  • ➤ Perkins Tonometer

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with complaints of blurry vision after cataract surgery. Fundus fluorescein angiography reveals a characteristic 'flower petals' appearance in the macula region. What is he most likely suffering from?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Irvine Gass Syndrome

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of progressive vision loss and night blindness. Upon examination, the patient displays characteristic retinal degeneration with peripheral bone spicule pigmentation. Which of the following syndromes is NOT likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Marfans syndrome.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of discharge, pain, and redness in his left eye. He states that his ophthalmologist surgically placed a "filter" in this eye 5 years ago to control his glaucoma. Visual acuity is 20/200 in this eye. Inspection reveals a very injected and swollen eye. You also note a very milky layer of fluid accumulating in the anterior chamber (Figure). What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea

questions.explanation: Ans. D) Bacterial endophthalmitis.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Berger’s space?

options.label: A
options.text: The cavity between the anterior hyaloid face and the iris.

options.label: B
options.text: A potential cavity formed due to the attachment of the lens to the posterior capsule.

options.label: C
options.text: The potential cavity between the lens and the vitreous body.

options.label: D
options.text: A space formed by the equator of the lens and the zonules of Zinn.

questions.correct_answer: C. The potential cavity between the lens and the vitreous body.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The potential cavity between the lens and the vitreous body.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Berger’s space, also called the retrolental space, is a potential cavity between the lens and the vitreous body and plays a role in maintaining their anatomical relationship.

questions.text: What is incorrect about this lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Consist of head, neck, and body

options.label: B
options.text: Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

questions.correct_answer: B. Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

questions.text: A patient with uncontrolled diabetes presents with blurry vision and early cataract formation. Which metabolic pathway in the lens becomes abnormally activated in hyperglycemia, contributing to cataract development?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sorbitol pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sorbitol pathway is activated in hyperglycemia, resulting in sorbitol accumulation and osmotic stress, leading to diabetic cataract formation.

questions.text: Which of the following systemic conditions is most commonly associated with the development of posterior subcapsular cataracts?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Myotonic dystrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myotonic dystrophy is a significant systemic cause of posterior subcapsular cataracts due to its effects on lens epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of ionizing radiation exposure develops progressive vision loss. The opacity is localized axially near the posterior capsule, causing significant disability. Which of the following symptoms is most characteristic of this type of cataract?

options.label: B
options.text: Glare and poor vision in bright light

questions.correct_answer: B. Glare and poor vision in bright light
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glare and poor vision in bright light

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior subcapsular cataracts cause significant glare and poor vision in bright light due to their central axial location.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key difference between diabetic and galactosemic cataracts?

options.label: A
options.text: Diabetic cataracts affect the lens nucleus, while galactosemic cataracts affect the lens cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Galactosemic cataracts are reversible, while diabetic cataracts are irreversible

options.label: C
options.text: Diabetic cataracts present with oil-droplet opacities, while galactosemic cataracts present with snowflake opacities

options.label: D
options.text: Galactosemic cataracts are unilateral, while diabetic cataracts are bilateral

questions.correct_answer: B. Galactosemic cataracts are reversible, while diabetic cataracts are irreversible
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Galactosemic cataracts are reversible, while diabetic cataracts are irreversible

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galactosemic cataracts can be reversed with early dietary restriction, while diabetic cataracts cause irreversible lens fiber damage due to sorbitol accumulation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic man presents with complaints of glare and blurred vision in both eyes, worse under bright light. Slit-lamp examination reveals a posterior subcapsular cataract. Which of the following best explains why this cataract causes more disability than other types of cataracts?

options.label: A
options.text: Its location near the nodal point maximally scatters incident light.

options.label: B
options.text: It primarily affects the peripheral cortical fibers, causing monocular diplopia.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to progressive yellowing of the lens and a myopic shift

options.label: D
options.text: It interferes with aqueous outflow, causing intraocular pressure to rise

questions.correct_answer: A. Its location near the nodal point maximally scatters incident light.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Its location near the nodal point maximally scatters incident light.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Posterior subcapsular cataracts cause significant visual disability due to their axial location, interfering with central vision and incident light.

questions.text: Which of the following is a drawback of multifocal intraocular lenses (IOLs) in cataract surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased risk of posterior capsule opacification

options.label: B
options.text: Poor contrast sensitivity in low-light conditions

options.label: D
options.text: Inability to protect against UV light

questions.correct_answer: B. Poor contrast sensitivity in low-light conditions
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Poor contrast sensitivity in low-light conditions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Multifocal IOLs may reduce contrast sensitivity, particularly in low-light conditions, due to their light-splitting design.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with complaints of progressive blurring of vision. Amsler grid testing finding is shown below. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Macular Degeneration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metamorphopsia on the Amsler grid is a key feature of macular disease, including macular degeneration.

questions.text: Which of the following surgical techniques is most effective in reducing the risk of posterior capsular opacification (PCO) in children after cataract surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: Lens aspiration with posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Extracapsular cataract extraction without posterior capsulorhexis

questions.correct_answer: B. Lens aspiration with posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lens aspiration with posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pediatric cataract surgery, posterior capsulorhexis with anterior vitrectomy significantly reduces the risk of posterior capsular opacification.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular findings is most specific for Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior uveitis with serous retinal detachment

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sugiura sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sugiura sign is a specific diagnostic finding in VKH syndrome, indicative of autoimmune melanocyte inflammation.
  • ➤ Sugiura sign

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of alkali injuries to the eye?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Limbal stem cell deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkali injuries cause deep tissue penetration leading to limbal stem cell loss, which is the most significant complication requiring advanced surgical intervention for corneal rehabilitation.

questions.text: Which surgical intervention is most appropriate for managing the condition seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nd:YAG laser anterior capsulotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nd:YAG laser anterior capsulotomy effectively manages anterior capsular phimosis by enlarging the contracted capsular opening.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral eyelid swelling and redness for three months. She complains of excessive tearing and photophobia. On examination, there is proptosis, conjunctival injection, and limited upward gaze. Which of the following extraocular muscles is most commonly involved in her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Inferior rectus is the most commonly involved extraocular muscle in thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy, leading to restricted upward gaze.

questions.text: Assertion : Recurrent chalazion should raise suspicion of sebaceous gland carcinoma. Reason : Chalazion is caused by lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland due to blockage of its duct.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true, but Reason is false.

options.label: D
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Recurrent chalazion may indicate underlying malignancy like sebaceous gland carcinoma and requires further evaluation.

questions.text: Match the following conditions (Column A) with their respective features (Column B): Column A: Trichiasis Distichiasis Madarosis Phthiriasis palpebrarum Column B: Presence of a second row of eyelashes Loss of eyelashes Infestation of eyelashes with lice Inward turning of eyelashes rubbing the cornea
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichiasis: Posterior misdirection of eyelashes causing them to rub against the cornea. Distichiasis: Presence of an additional row of eyelashes emerging from the Meibomian glands. Madarosis: Partial or complete loss of eyelashes. Phthiriasis palpebrarum: Infestation of eyelashes caused by crab lice, presenting with itching and nits.
  • ➤ Trichiasis: Posterior misdirection of eyelashes causing them to rub against the cornea.
  • ➤ Trichiasis:
  • ➤ Distichiasis: Presence of an additional row of eyelashes emerging from the Meibomian glands.
  • ➤ Distichiasis:
  • ➤ Madarosis: Partial or complete loss of eyelashes.
  • ➤ Madarosis:
  • ➤ Phthiriasis palpebrarum: Infestation of eyelashes caused by crab lice, presenting with itching and nits.
  • ➤ Phthiriasis palpebrarum:

questions.text: Which of the following stains is specifically used to detect devitalized corneal tissue and has virucidal properties?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rose Bengal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rose Bengal is a devitalized tissue stain with virucidal properties, valuable in diagnosing herpetic and other viral conjunctival conditions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with neovascularization of the iris (NVI). Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Retinitis pigmentosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Neovascularization of the iris is most commonly associated with ischemic retinal diseases (e.g., diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusions), inflammation (e.g., uveitis, VKH syndrome), tumors, or radiation exposure. Retinitis pigmentosa is not a typical cause of NVI.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painful blind eye secondary to endophthalmitis. The surgeon decides to preserve the scleral shell while removing all intraocular contents. What is the timeline for prosthesis placement in such cases?

options.label: B
options.text: After 2-3 weeks, with a small-sized prosthesis for support

options.label: C
options.text: After 6-8 weeks, with proper-sized prosthesis placement

questions.correct_answer: C. After 6-8 weeks, with proper-sized prosthesis placement
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) After 6-8 weeks, with proper-sized prosthesis placement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In evisceration, a small-sized prosthesis is placed after 2-3 weeks for support, and a proper-sized prosthesis is placed after 6-8 weeks to allow adequate healing.

questions.text: A slit lamp image of the iris is shown below. Which condition is most commonly associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Granulomatous uveitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koeppe nodules at the pupillary margin are pathognomonic for granulomatous anterior uveitis.
